reviewText: The Seven-Ups is one of three essential car chase movies from the early 70s, including Bullitt (the best) and The French Connection (car versus the el).  The Seven-Ups is an elite squad of police who go after criminals deserving seven or more years of prison--and they have tacit approval for unorthodox tactics.  And when things go wrong, the action gets rougher.  Watch it, you'll be glad you did.

reviewText: "Seven Ups is a classic..." thus read my review in the Hollywood High School News, 1973. Was I jumping the gun? I'm not so sure this film has withstood the test of time. It's derivation from the Best Picture of 1971, The French Connection, is obvious, so much so that Seven-Ups is effectively a sequel to The French Connection.Producer/Director Philip D'Antoni, who worked as Producer on The French Connection, and who assumes directorial duties here as well, is now the auteur of THIS film. He took Friedkin's highly successful, hard-boiled formula, and he ran with it. D'Antoni also produced the groundbreaking detective thriller, "Bullitt". Can he claim to own the genre? After Seven-Ups, it seems to me, D'Antoni ran out of gas. He even produced a film in 1973 called "The Connection".From the frantic humping and screeching of Don Ellis' string score, Robert Weiner's casting, police procedures that cross the line, tense urban-hospital melodrama a-la-Bullitt, surveillance stake-outs in the dingy streets, and the same, key cast members, this film looks, smells and feels like French Connection Part 2. The Seven Ups is a good film, but it's too similar...it doesn't have enough original ideas.Furthermore, the car chase is highly derivative of Bullitt. It starts in the city, jumps across some intersections, and ends up on a country highway with a pump shot to the front of Scheider's Pontiac, and the side-to-side banging of cars at high speed. Legendary stunt driver Bill Hickman is again the driver of the getaway car. Even the engine sound effects and the sizes and behavior of the vehicles are very much like Bullitt.There is also a "what-the-hell-is-going-on-here" scene between Roy Scheider and the stubble-haired "Captain" Inspector (Rex Everhart) that is highly reminiscent of Bullitt when Steve McQueen meets with Simon Oakland's "Captain Bennet" in a test of authority. Tony Lo Bianco again plays a brigand in the mobster mold, and there are reappearances by other key cast members from The French Connection.To be sure, the story is different from the French Connection, but only by a few degrees.That said, I still feel Seven-Ups is an excellent film, with memorable, hard-boiled performances from all involved. The Seven Ups is a pivotal work in the crime-drama genre. But not exactly groundbreaking.
summary: Hard-boiled detective drama, but with a lot of derivative elements

reviewText: Fans of movies like "The French Connection", "Bullitt", "Serpico", and any other great Cop action flicks should definitely enjoy this one. Keep in mind this was made long before "Die Hard" and "Lethal Weapon" came out so they didn't have the special effects, but they did have some incredible stunt people. The casting in this movie was exceptional. The actors do a wonferful job of making you feel they are the person they are portraying. The director did a great job too, and the sets will make you think you are in the heart of the city. I am a fan of Roy Scheider myself, and I think this is one of the best movies he ever made. Most people know Roy Scheider from his part as the main character Martin Brody, the Amity police chief, in the first two "Jaws" movies. "The Seven-Ups" probably has the second best car chase scene you will see in a movie. Like the other top movies I listed they took stock cars you would see on the street and beefed up the suspensions and engines.I personally rate "Bullitt" first, "French Connection" third, "Ronin" fourth, "Transporter" fifth, and "The Driver" sixth. Second in this group is exceptionally good. The reason I rate Bullitt higher is it was the original greatest car chase, Steve McQueen not only drove the Mustang he did the motorcycle stunt, hotter cars, and the hilly streets of San Francisco are more challenging than New York. I only mention this because someone didn't think second was good enough even though you have most the same people from Bullitt creating this chase scene and they even use the Bullitt soundtrack. The Seven-ups story is about a group of undercover cops taking on the toughest cases against the hardest criminals. You can tell that a great deal is borrowed from real life crime fighting. You will feel the gritty ambience of the streets of New York. You can almost smell the street vendors hot dogs. Don't miss this one. The price is good and I expect this will be a good quality DVD. I have not found any details on whether it will include any extras at this writing. If you like Scheider in this be sure to catch "Marathon Man", "Blue Thunder", and "Still of the Night".

reviewText: Philip D'Antoni isn't a name you hear mentioned often when the history of modern cinema is discussed, but he certainly deserves some credit for two notable contributions to film history. The first is the car chase. D'Antoni was the producer of Bullitt, The French Connection, and The Seven-Ups. Now there were certainly car chases before Bullitt, but they were usually done for comic effect as in It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World, or they were clumsily filmed scenes (lots of rear projection shots) of squad cars chasing bank robbers. In Bullitt and The French Connection the car chase became an action centrepiece, the equivalent of the cavalry charge in westerns and historical epics. D'Antoni's "modern" car chases looked and sounded real, and created a new kind of cinematic excitement. After The French Connection virtually no action film was complete unlesss it included one or more elaborately staged car chases.D'Antoni's other addition to film history is the creation of a sub-genre I'd call cop noir. Cop noir begins with The French Connection. If film noir was all about doomed lovers, laconic private detectives, and moody cinematography, cop noir was about documenting the decline and fall of American cities and the institutions that make them function as seen through cop eyes. Cop noir looks raw, sounds raw, and shows big American cities torn apart by street crime, organized crime, drug addiction, poverty, and corruption. Hard on the heels of The French Connection came Dirty Harry, Across 110th Street, Busting, Serpico, The Taking of Pelham 123, Badge 373, and a score of similar films. Bullitt isn't cop noir if only because Steve McQueen looks great, acts cool, mostly keeps his temper, and has a supermodel girlfriend before there were supermodels. Compare and contrast with Gene Hackman in The French Connection and you'll see what I mean.And that brings us to The Seven-Ups. The story has a pre-Jaws Roy Scheider leading a small team of N.Y.C. cops who go after villains wanted for crimes that earn sentences of seven years and up. Why seven years? Because it makes for a punny movie title. The film's title is a dud, but the film isn't. The Seven-Ups is essentially a sequel to Connection in everything but name. It has the same gritty look, Don Ellis scored both films, and it features possibly the best car chase of the three films D'Antoni produced.The plot has Scheider's team investigating why some of the city's crime bosses are being kidnapped. It turns out Scheider's main snitch, played by Tony Lo Bianco, is using information he gets from an unwitting Scheider to target wealthy criminals for kidnapping and ransom. Things are further complicated by the fact that snitch and cop are childhood friends.Things don't end well for one of them. The story is original and engaging, and might have been even better if D'Antoni hadn't decided to direct this film himself. He had no experience at directing and it shows on occasion. A couple of sequences, notably a scene in a car wash, are clumsily handled and feature a variety of glaring continuity errors.D'Antoni does redeem himself with the action sequences, which are quick, dirty and efficient, and the car chase, which is certainly as good as the one in Connection as well as being longer. D'Antoni the director also does a nice job with the actors, choosing an all-ugly cast of New York actors who bring a lot of verisimilitude to the film. And New York looks like, well, the New York you don't see in Woody Allen movies. This is Ratso Rizzo's N.Y.C.If you like to remember New York as being mad, bad and dangerous to visit, check out The Seven-Ups. You can read more of my reviews at JettisonCocoon dot com.

reviewText: There's nothing particularly special about the story. It's typical 70's cop drama stuff. Good guys vs. bad guys, etc. But,... there are some good performances in this film. But the whole reason to watch it is the car chase scene. It's one of the best ever filmed and the fact that it was shot in NYC is truly astounding. The stunt driver is actually one of the bad guys "Bill Hickman". He did the driving in The French Connection (another awesome NYC car chase) and Bullitt with Steve McQueen.  I give it 5 stars because I like those old cop dramas. They were gritty old NY.

reviewText: Expecting an East Coast "Magnum Force" I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of "The Seven-Ups".  Though it has the pedigree of "The French Connection" with that film's producer, Philip D'Antoni, taking on directing chores and Roy Scheider reprising his Buddy Russo character this film distinguishes itself from it's predecessor.  Exciting action and gritty locations add to the film's flavor.  The film's plot involving an elite police unit whose efforts are scuttled by renegade cops kidnapping mobsters is intriguing.  Scheider anchors the film superbly.  Tony LoBianco (another "Connection" alum) has a dynamite turn as a hood playing the angles.  For those of you who've seen "The French Connection" a dozen or more times like I have another castmember from that film appears here, Joe Spinnel.

reviewText: It remains in the shadow of its famous predecessor, 'The French Connection,' but 'The Seven Ups' is required viewing if you're in the mood for a no-nonsense, unglorified NYC police story.  There's an incredible end  to the car chase, the film's trademark, but watch it for the  straightforward acting, jolting plot twists, and unvarnished picture of  workaday New York in the '70s.  The music lends an eerie mood, and there's  plenty of small touches of realism. My favorite is a grim view of a muddy  New Jersey wasteland--trains of oblivious commuters roar by the cops and  villains on foot.  'The Seven Ups' is a rare breed--it looks like it could  have happened the way it was filmed.  Unspectacular but rewarding.

reviewText: The director of "Seven Ups" also produced "The French Connection." He managed to hold onto some of what made 'Connection' great, but he also lost a few things.Roy Scheider plays an unorthodox detective in an elite undercover squad in the NYC police department. When he enters a case involving mob guys who are kidnapped for ransom by men parading as cops, he finds himself in up to his neck.This looks a lot like "The French Connection." The locales are great. The viewer gets a good feel for the city. A lot of varying locations were used and the establishing shots really help set a mood. You feel as though you're on the streets with these guys. Unfortunately, that's about all it has going for it. The script is broad and tepid. There's barely enough, story-wise, to fill a one hour TV show. And the directing and acting border on comatose. Roy Scheider is Okay. Tony LaBianco couldn't seem to get a hold on his character. He's supposed to be a fringe mob guy, and lifelong buddy to Scheider, playing both sides of the fence, but he's lacking the wiles, the shiftiness to be convincing. All the other characters are likewise lackluster. The directing, save for a pretty nifty car chase, is leaden. A scene where one of Scheider's crew gets shot has nowhere near the adrenalin it needs to pull it off. What should have been fast and maddening nearly dozes off.This is a shame. With a tighter, more involved script, and more adroit directing, this could have been a real winner.
summary: NYC is the Real Star of this Film

reviewText: This film gave me one of my weirdest movie moments back in 1973: as a kidnapped mobster is driven down Fordham Road in the Bronx, you can glimpse the Valentine movie theater out the car's back window.  The first time I saw that scene I was sitting in that theater, giving the action an eerie immediacy.Legend has it that Phil D'Antoni directed this film out of exasperation, feeling that he had gotten no credit for his contributions to the gritty, ground-breaking look of two classic crime films, "Bullit" and "The French Connection", both of which he Produced.  While "The Seven Ups" does not rise to the level of those other films, it does vividly capture the decaying landscape of New York City at that time and the documentary-style feel perfected in "The French Connection".  Excellent location shooting (particularly in the Arthur Avenue section of the Bronx), good story, very well done.  The car chase is exciting, but forget everything you know about NYC geography or you will spend the entire sequence saying "Whaaa- ?"
summary: Quintessential 1970's cop movie, dynamite car chase

reviewText: This is the third gem of a trio of cops vs mobs, set in the real streets of urban decay. Even though I see parallels that started withBullitt [Blu-ray] and which were carried over toThe French Connection [Blu-ray], one can really get a sense of both flicks in the Seven-Ups. If you like the first two films, be sure to get this.It's definitely not as good. The plot starts a little slow, and one can hear the forced acting in some of the characters. But the movie as a whole picks up pace by capitalizing on the grit and flavor of exploiting the realistic scenery of a then-largely-ignored parts of Manhattan and the Bronx.One might almost think of the Seven-Ups as a wannabe sequel to French Connection by using a number of actors who were great in that movie. Roy Scheider plays the lead cop this time, and Tony Lo Bianco is now the character of interest and information that has helped the Seven-Ups squad corner and bust gangsters by using questionable tactics.Look for Bill Hickman, the terrific stuntman-turned-actor, who made the muscle cars sing and bounce all over the west and east coasts in all three films (unfortunately his last acting role was as "Bo" in this film). Also, watch Richard Lynch, who rode shotgun, as the greedy "Moon," with Hickman - Lynch actually passed away just two months ago.The big chase scene took elements of both Bullitt and French Connection, but it still played out well. I would give French Connection 9 stars, Bullitt 8, and Seven-Ups 7 stars - not a strong vote, but it doesn't deserve less than that. While Seven-Ups isn't as polished, and seems to have been made more for trying to add cash flow from the popularity of the previous films, it's still entertaining and enjoyable.

reviewText: It's been a long wait, but finally it is coming out on DVD! Outstanding action/dramatic cop film from the 70's. You can just feel the atmosphere in this film and become immersed in it. Great car chase, choreographed by the same fellow who did the chase in Bullitt. Some trivia...the car sounds during the chase are the same ones from Bullitt! Listen for the shifts, but note that the car Scheider is driving is an automatic! Also note that the guy driving the car fleeing from Scheider is the same actor who drove the Charger fleeing from McQueen in Bullitt! Still it plays well and the chase is VERY exciting, a classic chase all in its own rite. The cars involved (a Pontiac Ventura for Scheider and a Pontiac Grand Ville for the bad guys)are not as glamorous as the Mustang and Charger in Bullit, but seem appropriate for the big cold eastern city of New York depicted here. A very good chase indeed. The rest of the movie is just as good and I've been patiently watching and waiting for this to come out on DVD. I first saw this movie when I was a kid in the mid 70's and its been a favorite of mine every since! If you like Bullitt, French Connection, To Live and Die in LA and other great cop action/chase films, then you will LOVE this!!
summary: Great 70's Cop Movie!!  Super car chase!!

reviewText: In this spin-off from the French Connection Roy Scheider is the leader of an elite team of cops (the titular soft drinks) who target high-profile crooks. New York's gangsters are being held to ransom by extortionists posing as the Seven-Ups and strike back against the cops.Set against the bleak, imposing backdrop of early 70s New York, a time in which almost every building was decaying and all new architecture was a brutalist, concrete nightmare, the Seven-Ups is every bit as old school as it could possibly be. If you like the cold, paranoid atmosphere of movies likeRonin [Blu-ray] or the retro-style ofBullitt [Blu-ray] you'll definitely get a kick out of this.Aesthetically, the film is horrific, with ugly people and bad fashion all over the place. It's an abomination of bad taste and degradation. But as a simple cop thriller it's got all the right moves. The stand-out car chase at the half-way point is quite impressive and it's a shame that it seems to have been forgotten among the ubiquitous "Best Car Chase" countdowns on TV and on the Internet.Fans of theThe French Connection [Blu-ray], cop thrillers or overlooked 70s movies that represent an attitude to filmmaking and life long since gone should definitely check it out.

summary: The Seven-Ups,better than Bullitt.GM,Pontiac vs Pontiac.

reviewText: "The Seven-Ups" is a thrilling 1973 crime drama about a no nonsense group of plain clothes cops who use unorthodox methods to collar their targets. The lead is played by Roy Scheider, which is in some ways a reprisal of his role in "The French Connection", which was released two years prior to this film. The character's names are different, but the worlds they inhabit are pretty much the same. The New York underworld is the setting for both films, and it would be hard to find another movie which shows the criminals of the day with better clarity. Even though this movie takes place in New York, the characters and themes could be applied to most urban areas with a strong organized crime presence.Scheider's character goes simply by "Buddy". He leads his plain clothes unit in quasi-undercover stings against various crews that happen to be running scams or heists in the area. The real hinge point of this movie is the Vito character, played by Tony Lo Bianco, who also appeared in "The French Connection" as Sal, the frontman for the heroin smuggling ring. Vito is a cunning rat who enjoys his Confidential Informant status and the immunity that comes with it. I thought his performance really made the movie realistic and shows the treacherous nature of informants. It's a lot like Peter Boyle's "Dylan" character in "Eddie Coyle".These two movies are alike in so many ways. There are several parties involved in the series of events that comprise this movie. The situations involved reminded me very much of the Winter Hill gang/Mullen Gang/Mafia type of interplay in Boston that made the era in question very unstable. There were numerous "independent" crews which popped up on the radar, many of which went as quickly as they came. Many of these involved stick ups and heists, with the perps usually ending up in a tight spot. The locations for this movie also looked a lot like the Revere/ East Boston area, so for any fan of "The Friends of Eddie Coyle", this movie has the exact same era and feel.Buddy's "Seven Ups" don't exactly play by the rules (according to Buddy's superior officer), but the seven plus year bits they secure for almost every case make them highly effective. There was a definite similarity between Buddy and Richard Jordan's FBI Agent in "Eddie Coyle", both of whom use informants and are somewhat ruthless in flipping their sources around.  The real heart of the story comes when an independent crew starts ripping off Mafia bookies while posing as police officers. Richard Lynch does a great job as a long haired 70's wildman stickup artist, known as "Moon". There is also a car chase scene that is as good as any I've seen from the era, and is consistent with the chase scenes in director Philip D'Antoni's previous mob flicks, "French Connection" and "Bullitt."
summary: Roy Scheider as mob-busting police Lt.

reviewText: THE SEVEN-UPS is one of the grittier and nastier of the "rogue cop" films of the 1970s. While it lacks greatness as a movie, it does a terrific job of establishing the half-lawless atmosphere of the "old" NYPD, where results were never questioned and the line between cop and clook was smeared almost out of existence. It also showcases the darker side of the great Roy Scheider, who could play one nasty S.O.B. when he wanted to.SEVEN is the story of Buddy (Roy Scheider), a New York detective in charge of an elite undercover unit known as "The Seven-Ups", so-called because they won't touch a case unless it puts the criminal away for at least seven years or more. Through his old neighborhood pal Vito (Tony Lo Bianco), a mobbed-up undertaker, Buddy gets the dope on most everything going on in the underworld. Nobody, however, seems to know much about the sudden rash of kidnappings rocking the Mafia - one bigshot wiseguy after another is being yanked off the street by cop-impersonators and held for big ransoms. Who is to blame for this daring, brutal series of crimes? Certain people in the department think it might be Buddy and his 7-Ups... and certain very angry mobsters agree. When an undercover ends up dead as a result, Buddy and his surviving troops go looking for information; but to get to the kidnappers they have to go through the mob. Literally.THE SEVEN-UPS has a lot going for it. It's inspired by real events (the kidnappings did take place, for one thing, and many teams of NYPD detectives did "go rogue" over the years), and grittiness pervades the entire film. All the actors are old pros, from Scheider down to the ubiquitous Richard Lynch, and the cinematography is oddly beautiful considering the ugliness of the early-70s New York landscape (practically dystopian in its shabbiness). There are several sequences which take place in car-washes where the tension and music combine to reach almost unbearable levels of suspense. And yet the film always feels genuine; and even the massive car chase, sort of "The French Connection" meets "Bullitt", doesn't look like choreographed but rather real mayhem. The writer clearly understood that in police work, as in military life, schemes often go terribly wrong, confusion is the norm, the unwritten rule is law, and snitches (like spies) can play both ends off the middle like nobody's business.Balanced against this is a sluggish pace in the early going, a disjointed storyline, and, in the habit of late 60s/1970s movies, a decided lack of characters who arouse sympathy from the audience. Buddy's not a bad guy, he's nicer than Cloudy Russo, who Scheider played in THE FRENCH CONNECTION, but in terms of methodology, he's one of those cops who is only distinguishable from a Mafia thug by virtue of the fact that he has a badge. Threatening to carve up a mobster's wife's face with a broken vase as she sobs "No more! No more!" is difficult for the viewer to stomach. Some of the dialogue, too, falls into crime-story cliché (two guys talking about the old neighborhood). Ultimately, THE SEVEN-UPS is just a bit too distant from its characters; it stands back and observes them coldly, instead of forcing us to pick a side and care about it.Having said that, I liked the film. It does what it sets out to do, which is show just how blurry the line can become between cops and crooks, and how the old Mafia cliché that "it's just business" couldn't be a bigger lie. To these guys, good and bad, it's all strictly personal.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Seven-Ups is often thought of as the unofficial sequel to The French Connection.  This is because it was produced (and directed) by Connection producer Phillip D'Antoni, features Connection alum Roy Scheider, Tony Lo  Bianco, Bill Hickman, and Benny Marino, and includes a Connection-esque car  chase.The other relationship the film has to French Connection is that  the story is by Salvatore "Sonny" Grosso, one of the real life  Connection cops.The story is very good.  The Seven-Ups are members of a  special undercover investigative unit of the NYPD; the nickname comes from  the seven years or up sentences the perps they collar usually get from the  judge.  Buddy (Scheider) is their leader, alongside Mingo, Borelli, and  Ansel.The film establishes the Seven-Ups in a very entertaining opening  where they bust an antique shop that's a stash house for counterfeit loot.  Later, after the name of a Mob-connected bail bondsman turns up on a  wiretap, Buddy debriefs his chief informant (Tony Lo Bianco) on several  Mobsters being tailed.But there is more here than meets the eye.  Two  men posing as policemen (Bill Hickman and Richard Lynch) arrest Mob leader  Max Kalish, drive him out of town, and knock him out.  Then they collect a  hefty ransom and dump Kalish, bound and gagged, in an empty lot.The two  have also grabbed other "wiseguys," and next they grab Festa, the  Mob-connected bail bondsman, but are seen by Buddy and Ansel.  The  Seven-Ups infiltrate Ansel as a limo driver at a funeral home where Kalish  and others ponder what to do next.  When one of the thugs' bodyguards  notices a loose wire under Ansel's pantleg, the drivers are summoned inside  - unknown to Buddy and Borelli, who've spilled coffee on their hands just  as the drivers are summoned inside.  Ansel is dragged to the basement and  his cover blown.  Thinking Ansel is part of the kidnap gang, Kalish stuffs  him into a car trunk and has friend Carmine Cottello drive him to the  location where a new ransom is supposed to be dropped.  When Mingo, posing  as a cab driver, sees that Ansel is not with the limos, Buddy and Borelli  tail Cottello to a car wash, where the kidnap gang grabs his car and drives  into a garage.  There they force him to open the trunk, but he runs for it.  They shoot him down and blast open the trunk, and are naturally shocked to  find a now-dead cop inside.Then ensues a car chase that ranks with  French Connection and D'Antoni's slick masterpiece Bullitt.  Buddy chases  the gunmen through New York City and into the countryside, but when the two  cars fuse door to door, the gunmen run Buddy head-on into the back of a  stalled 18-wheeler.Buddy and Borelli grab Kalish and learn of the other  kidnappings.  Kalish lists Mobsters who've been nabbed, and when Buddy  checks his own list of suspects, he realizes to his fury that his informant  is the one collecting the ransoms.The ending is very chilling when  Buddy confronts his informant and leaves him pleading for his life at the  prospect that Buddy will leak to the Mob of the man's role.Despite an  excess of voice-looping, the film is very well done and well worth checking  out.
summary: Grossly Underrated Cop Drama Follows French Connection

reviewText: The spare black and white titles unfold, the grim Don Ellis soundtrack music starts, and we're thurst into the real sequel to "The French Connection".  Roy Scheider (Buddy) heads up the elite police unit of the movie title whose members usually ignore a few laws when busting criminals, such as gathering evidence without a search warrant.  However, two crooks (Bill Hickman and the extremely unlikeable Richard Lynch) are going around New York City impersonating police officers and kidnapping mafia guys and holding them for ransom--and Buddy finds his unit under suspicion for those kidnappings.  The long car chase alone is a work of art and a short movie by itself--the logical way that it plays out, the editing, and even the acting are all first-rate.  Michael Bay--take note:  in a car chase, the skill of the drivers is shown not by how many cars you hit but by how many cars and buildings you DON'T hit!  The scenes at the car wash also are done with some amazing editing--the fast editing cuts turn the rusted old carwash (the place where the ransom money is seized) into something that represents everything that drives the story--money, greed, violence, and betrayal.  Altogether, a really great cop movie from the 70's.
summary: The car chase alone is a work of art!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was one of a trilogy of hard hitting cop thrillers from the time, which began with Bullit, and continued with The French Connection.  I have owned copies of both previously, but traded them in, but interestingly, decided to keep a hold of this one.Quickly, Seven ups refers to a group of cops whose use unorthodox methods to entrap the criminals they pursue and they end up doing seven years in jail or more.  No six months or suspended sentences nonsense here.  Roy Schieder is electrifying in the lead, having no doubt been given the part because of his support work in The French Connection, so I guess it's a promotion of sorts!Like with Bullit and The French Connection, the standout scene is a car chase and in my view, I think it's the best of the lot.  Okay, for three reasons; firstly, it's as gripping, if not more so than the other ones in Connection and Bullit, except to be predantic, French Connection wasn't strictly a car-car chase, but it was a tough act to follow nonetheless, and they did it with this; secondly, it's over a longer distance and so the attention has to be sustained for longer and it still manages to grip; thirdly, (spoiler alert, careful!), the ending to the chase is sudden and it is the wrong one who wins.  The pursuer loses.  That gives it a harder edge funnily enough.  But there is a further payoff to come.  There is also a very deserved mention here for the stunt driver who worked on both previous films and I am not sure if he did the stuntowrk on this too, Bill Hickman.  If he did co-ordinate it or even perform it, then hats off to the best stuntdriver that Hollywood has ever seen.

reviewText: Cult crime film, that's virtually unknown by many film fans, however this gritty 1973 crime thriller is still edgy and captivating viewing over thirty years later, and effectively captures the tense and often violent relations between the NYC detectives and their hoodlum prey. The term "seven ups" was actually coined in the late 1960's in relation to a special squad of detectives operating in New York City who were pursuing high profile felons convictable of prison terms of seven years or more.Ex-NYC detective Sonny Grosso ( the real life "Cloudy" of "The French Connection" fame ) penned the story for "The Seven Ups" based upon some of his personal experiences and observations in the NYC police department.  A steely and youthful Roy Scheider is the lead actor portraying uncompromising detective "Buddy Manucci". Scheider was at that time just breaking through to mainstream cinema, and had recently gained high praise from critics for his role as Gene Hackman's cop buddy in the sensational "The French Connection"...plus, Scheider would soon become a familiar face as "Chief Brody" in 1975's biggest blockbuster "Jaws". Fellow actor from "The French Connection", Tony Lo Bianco appears in "The Seven Ups" as an oily, two faced mob undertaker, manipulating both his criminal cohorts and his friend Buddy via the use of sensitive information on the mob's business dealings. The plot of the film primarily centres around the double crossing activities of Vito ( Lo Bianco ) as he uses his child hood friend Buddy ( Scheider ) to identify potential mob identities that Vito's crooked partners can kidnap and hold for an exhorbitant ransom. Both the cops and the mob are rattled as they struggle to identify the mole betraying the fingered mob bosses for hefty ransom's. Vito's kidnapping colleagues are played by swarthy Richard Lynch ( Starsky & Hutch, Vampire, Invasion USA ), and shifty Bill Hickman ( one of Hollywood's top stunt drivers ) and a key sequence of the film has the two merciless kidnappers flee a garage after a shooting to be pursued by Scheider in one of the finest car chases you will ever see on film !( Forget all the nit-picking criticisms about which direction they are driving on various expressway's, and being on the wrong side of railings, and tour buses etc etc......the fact is that the car chase between the kidnappers in an Oldsmobile Delta 88 and Scheider pursuing in a Pontiac Ventura is brilliantly photographed, well paced, exciting and keep's your eyes glued to the screen ! )The film was shot during an icy NYC winter, and the use of various bleak and mud spattered industrial estate's, warehouse's and rail freight yard locations around NYC, give the movie a really strong "street" feel that strongly parallels the grimy under belly of the various crooked characters peopling the cast. One can only hope that this under rated piece of classic 70's crime cinema eventually makes it to DVD !!  Highly Recommended !!
summary: Cult 1973 crime thriller with plenty of style and substance!

reviewText: This movie was probably intended as a B movie to pad out a studio's production list.  What resulted however, is a great action/suspense movie with one of the BEST automobile chase scenes (Bullit and the French Connection are the other two) in the business.  Roy Schieder is very good in this film.  It has turned into a classic.

reviewText: The Seven-Ups (1973) promises a story that's rooted in the underworld, and deliversall of that, and more! The marketing of the movie is very accurate.This picture, as a DVD, is superb, from a cinematographical point of view (by Urs Furrer)as is the music, reminiscent of Bela Bartok's String Quartet, for example ( by Don Ellis.)The images have none of that post 1990's "Video Tape" look to it, that often makes moviesmerely TV-grade, lusterless, colorless, meaningless. Kudos to the camera equipment used,and the DVD transfer specialists. We have a super sharp, high resolution, super clearoutstanding filming here.This movie surely was a hit on its release date, in the 70's, because it delivers thrills,and action, with a dream-like quality that doesn't overdo it, taking the viewers for arollercoaster of a ride throughout the 103 mins. This is what entertainment is all about,with a special appreciation for the absolutely spectacular car chases lasting over 10 to 15minutes, in downtown Bronx, NYC, while real people are walking the streets, and real carsdriving downtown in both directions, during real, authentic deadly dangerous stunts, coupledwith impressive GTA- like engine and rubber  tires sound effects. It's a thrill to see thePolice fire shotguns at those racing their vehicles downtown, and real  cars being smashedat high speeds, (without any computerized, hocus pocus special effects  that toooften takes viewers for granted in  terms of what will hit the mark or not.) Thisis the best car chase I've seen to date, in a movie.  The shootouts are also totally realistic.Roy Scheider is a no-nonsense, low-key approach officer, that is a paradox, in that hefights his own propensity to calmness, with the need to get results, as a businessmanknows one must, and as an employee knows one must to keep one's job. As such, the endsjustify the means, in an era of widespread, out of control corruption and crime, to avoidvigilantism, by having undercover officers use the same methods, and play by the same bookof rules as those they are trying to catch.Richard Lynch, playing Moon, is a crowd pleaser: his facial expressions always seemgenuine, and comical, such is the ease the actor has in showing emotion ...fear, greed,the urge for violence, etc.Ken Kercheval (better known as Cliff Barnes from the 1980's series Dallas), has a shortpart as a member of the undercover team, known as the 7-Up's, but has that vitality inhis acting that also was a trade mark in the TV series.A remarkable aspect that clearly brings a lot of class and style to the picture (as doesthe classical genre music) are the 3 piece suits and ties the gangsters wear, as do the 7Ups, their shiny black shoes; yet this also obviously overshoots the target in terms ofthe movie -going audience, who will obviously be of  a younger crowd, jeans-wearing, andpop music hearing.A bizarre moment is Schneider actually eating half of an apple live on camera, perhapsimprovized.The large, heavy, over-sized overcoats perhaps stem from the fashion of the day, since itseems a bit theatrical in nature, even considering the 0 degrees outside Wintertime weather of NYC.The only aspect that is dated, are some the cars, - American-style gas guzzlers -the Black and White TV's and the police sirens.Interestingly, the phenomenon of kidnappings in public for randoms - often seen indeveloping and in third-world countries - is brought to the forefront here, as an effectiveand easy way in raking in several 100 large, as the Italian Mob is shown shaken down bya rogue crew of members from the underworld. This is suggested as a consequence of theshylock business having lost its profitability from too many players, and the need forsome to diversify and maintain revenue and profit levels.The very realistic and common practice usage of confidential informants is introducedto viewers, who in this case, are shown one playing both sides of the law , with incomplete,often false information given to the officer, Schneider.For the most part, the dialog is impeccable, except for a few overdubbed moments,lasting only a few minutes, during which the lips of the actors  don't match the words heard.As the trailer says, this film is about "dirty trick cops that even the  regular police are afraidof!" reviewText: I went to watch a car chase and a movie broke out.  This is truly one of the great car chases in movie history and it seems to go on forever.  In reality, any cop who conducts this kind of chase would be severely disciplined for endangerment, but hey, that's entertainment!  Take away the chase and the movie isn't really very good, but there are some nice gritty shots of NY.  A good deal of the cast and crew is recycled from the French Connection, an infinitely better film.  Worth seeing once.  If you're on a time budget, scan directly to the chase and get on w/ your life....

reviewText: Flush with the success of French Connection 1, Philip D'Antoni returns as producer - and now director - for another hard-hitting crime story.  This time, stars Roy Scheider and Tony LoBianco are supplemented by a superb group of character actors.  There are plenty of cinema verite street scenes, a chilling music score from Don Ellis and a crazy car chase, of course.Buddy Manucci (Scheider) leads 'the Seven-Ups,' a team that has been given a green light to use unorthodox methods to bring down the crooks -  this time for real: prison for seven years or up.  After crashing a midtown antique shop fronting for counterfeiters, they celebrate back at the station but face growing unease among the brass about their methods.  One of Buddy's tipsters is his childhood friend Vito Lucia (LoBianco), now a Mafia undertaker.  In turn, Vito has also been selling tips to a gang with a daring specialty: kidnapping Mafia bosses for ransom.  The string of deceptions leads to a string of disasters -  a botched surveillance operation, one of Buddy's men killed in action and suspicion that the Seven-Ups are involved in the kidnap scheme.  There's no romance and no happy ending; rough justice is meted out - roughly.Character actors are the unappreciated foot soldiers of movies.  Here are a few worth knowing:Robert Burr -  Lt. Hanes, a straight-arrow cop with grave doubts about the Seven-Ups.Rex Everhart -  Inspector Gilson, Buddy's gruff boss who supports his efforts.Bill Hickman and Richard Lynch -  Bo and Moon, menacing street thugs and kidnappers.Larry Haines -  a voice-over and soap opera actor who does a credible turn as a Mafia loan shark.Check them out on IMDB and Wikipedia; they had great careers and made a great contribution to theatre and film.The Seven-Ups and The Verdict
summary: More gritty action from the French Connection crew -

reviewText: While less well known than "Bullitt" or "The French Connection", the Philip D'Antoni film "The Seven Ups" certainly deserves a place in the genre of tough gritty cop shows with car chases and shoot-outs."The Seven Ups" is another example of how such films can act as a sort of time capsule of the era as well as surviving as powerful entertainment for the modern audience. The wonderful New York street scenes of the 70's are unavailable today except as a fake studio bound period piece.(It's good news by the way that this great old film is finally preserved on the DVD format as well as this old VHS.)

Roy Scheider and Tony LoBianco are great as childhood buddies on opposite sides of the law in this police thriller.  Great scenes of NYC as it was in 1973, and characters with fedoras... cigarette smoking, elevated trains, big gas-guzzling cars, Grand Central Station, railroad yards, long sideburns, miniskirts, nurses in old-time white uniforms, a real look at how life was in the early 70's.

reviewText: What was it about the 70's...a decade that begged to be parodied--almost while we were still living in it? Watching "The Seven Ups", just released on DVD, its pretty obvious what was so "strange" about the 70's. Everything is so extreme.  The clothing is extreme; the poverty is extreme; the automobiles are extreme; everything is either "suede" or "broken glass". For all of the "schlock" that the 70's produced, there was a group of incredible crime/cop films that came out of that era.  Sort of a 70's "noir". In "The Seven Ups" Roy Scheider plays the leader of a "special squad" of police dealing with offenders whose crimes wil guarantee them a prison sentence of "7 years or up" hence the rather misleading title of the film. I hadn't seen this film in over 25 years when I recently purchased it, and watching it is  a time capsule of the gritty urban 70's. What really surprised me, rewatching it, though, was how much subsequent movie and tv crime shows "ripped off" from this film. That's not to say that this film didn't have its own larceny...there is a car chase designed to out-do "The French Connection" and "Bullitt".  But it is in the plot and character construction that this film, and some of its contemporaries, set a style that shows 30 years later are still emulating. Its character driven; plot driven; and action filled. Watching this movie, I could almost smell the diesel fumes of the transit buses I used to ride in downtown Baltimore in the 1970s. Watch it as a historical curiosity; watch it as a parody; but you'll also realize that you're watching a fine example of tight story telling that is still influencing Tony Soprano and his competition today.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The "Seven-Ups" are an elite special unit from within the New York Police Department headed by the tough and no nonsense detective named "Buddy" played by Roy Scheider. Buddy has no problem stepping outside the law to dish out his brand of justice and he uses questionable tactics to bring down the criminals. When a pair of police impersonators named Moon and Bo pull off a number of mob kidnappings, Buddy's boys are called into action and that's when the real fun starts.20th Century Fox presents the "Seven-Ups" in both full and widescreen versions on the same disc. The picture and sound are very impressive and I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of both. It's too bad that the sound wasn't remastered in 5.1 Dolby Digital given its awesome soundtrack and incredible chase sequence. The DVD features include a theatrical teaser and trailer for the movie. A special featurette: anatomy of a car chase, behind the scenes feature is located on the widescreen version in the special features menu.The "Seven-Ups" is a tough gritty, high octane thriller and it delivers the goods right to the very end. Character actor Richard Lynch plays the bad guy named Moon and he's very convincing in his role, so much that you just want to blow him away. Fans of Bullitt will notice that Moons partner Bo is played by Bill Hickman, the same guy who drove the charger in Bullitt. Veteran actor Tony Lo Bianco is in fine form and delivers a good performance as Vito Lucia, Buddy's down and out childhood friend turned snitch. In my opinion the car chase sequence alone was worth the price of this movie. If you're a fan of Bullitt and the French Connection, then the "Seven-Ups" may be for you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Watching The Seven-Ups, all I could think of was that if The French Connection sequel had starred Roy Scheider, this would be the movie.  Really though, this is a solid, entertaining movie and better than most crime dramas from the period.  Scheider plays Buddy Mancini, the leader of a small but specialized group of NY cops called the Seven-Ups (in reference to how long the sentences are for the crooks they put away) who seem to get results when no one else can.  But Buddy's crew runs into some trouble when mobsters start being kidnapped and ransomed off, supposedly by the police.  The Seven-Ups obviously know it's not them doing it, but can they find out who is behind the scheme?  The first 30 minutes or so are a little slow as the storyline is spelled out, but the rest of the movie really picks up speed, including one of the best car chases ever done.  It's a shame this chase doesn't get the accolades of a Bullitt or The French Connection, but it's right up there.  A sometimes confusing plot, but not enough to detract from the movie overall, The Seven-Ups is more than a safe bet if you're a fan of 1970s crime dramas and thrillers.Roy Scheider is really the only big name in the cast for his role as Buddy Mancini.  Scheider is very good in the part and you feel for the guy without knowing too much about his background.  He always was a likable actor, and his Buddy Mancini is no different as he tries to figure out what's going on with the mob kidnappings.  The rest of the Seven-Ups include Victor Arnold as Barrilli, Jerry Leon as Mingo, and Ken Kercheval as Ansel.  Little backstory is given to Mancini's team, but in a few brief scenes, the viewer really gets a sense for how close these four are and how good they are at their jobs.  Tony Lo Bianco plays Vito Lucia, a source of Buddy's who is trying to move up in the world.  Larry Haines plays Max Kalish, a mobster who's fed up with all the kidnappings.  Richard Lynch and Bill Hickman (of Bullitt fame) play Moon and Bo, the two crooks pulling off the mob kidnappings at the orders of a superior.For such a low price as I'm writing this, under $8, the DVD is a can't miss.  The movie is presented in widescreen, always a bonus, and looks great.  The only special feature is a nine-minute featurette about the organization and planning of the epic 10-minute car chase that comes about halfway through the movie that was made during filming.  No trailers or interviews, but a good featurette either way.  If you haven't seen this movie, give it a try, I came away impressed.  Check out The Seven-Ups!

reviewText: Directed by Academy Awarding winner Philip D'Antoni (The French Connection,Bullitt), The Seven-Ups (1973) is a gritty and atmospheric crime drama, that follows the activities of a group of New York City undercover cops, as the take on organized crime.  Roy Scheider (Jaws,Seaquest,Blue Thunder) stars as police Lt. Buddy Manucci, the leader of the "Seven Ups", a special unit that employs questionable methods to get results.  The mobsters have more to worry about than the cops, as an unknown group of men is kidnapping bosses, and holding them for ransom.A blown undercover operation and a visit to a car wash, leads to the film's action set piece, a high speed car chase through the streets of New York, that follows in the tradition of D'Antoni's other films, The French Connection, and Bullitt.  After one of his men is killed, Mannuci resorts to extreme measures to find those responsible.Similar in some respects to The French Connection (1971) and Bullitt (1968), The Seven-Ups is a tough straightforward tale, where the cops and the crooks seem to employ similar methods.  Fans of D'Antoni's previous films, should also appreciate this one.
summary: the seven-ups work to clean up the tough streets of nyc...

reviewText: The Seven-Ups was producer-turned-director Philip D'Antoni's attempt to outdo his earlier Bullitt and The French Connection but it falls flat because of a lack of starpower and a story that just doesn't matter. If anything its more a premise than a plot - a cop is unaware that his main informer is actually using him to get information on which mobsters to kidnap - and has characterization that never rises to the level of paper thin: despite a few "just a coupla kids from the old neighborhood" lines, the characters simply aren't there, leaving Roy Scheider often seeming on the verge of being completely lost while Tony Lo Bianco's hesitancy all too often seems more like desperation for something to latch on to. The car chase is good but not that good in a film that doesn't have enough going for it for that to be enough and which sorely lacks fizz.Fox's DVD isn't a bad package - widescreen 1.85:1 and fullscreen transfers, teaser and full trailer and a vintage short on the shooting of the car chase.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great flick from a time when these raw, gritty films brought people back into movie theaters after a long decline in attendance.  Contains one of the definitive car chase scenes, shot live on the streets of New York City.  Roy Scheider and Tony LoBianco turn in great performances.  A great night of entertainment, and if you remember the New York City of the 1970's, before it was sanitized and primped for bored (and boring) suburban tourists cattle herding themselves through our once real streets with their shopping bags of overpriced junk, you will long for the time when the City was actually a real, working city - warts and all.
